column1: Jinan (Chinese: 济南; alternately romanized as Tsinan) is the capital of Shandong province in Eastern China. With a population of was 6.8 million as of the 2010 census
column2: it is the second-largest city in Shandong after Qingdao. The area of present-day Jinan has played an important role in the history of the region from the earliest beginnings of civilization and has evolved into a major national administrative
column3: economic
column4: and transportation hub. The city has held sub-provincial administrative status since 1994. Jinan is often called the "Spring City" for its famous 72 artesian springs.Jinan is also one of the top 100 cities in the world by scientific research as tracked by the Nature Index according to the Nature Index 2020 Science Cities. The city is home to several major universities
column5: notably Shandong University
column6: one of China's most prestigious universities as a member of the Project 985.

column1: == Names ==
As the letter N can be both syllable-final and syllable-initial in Mandarin Chinese
column2: Hanyu Pinyin recommends that the city's name be spelled "Ji'nan" to avoid ambiguity with words pronounced "Jin'an" (e.g. 金安). This practice is however widely ignored.

column1: The modern-day name Jinan literally means "south of the Ji" and refers to the old Ji River that had flowed to the north of the city until the middle of the 19th century. The Ji River disappeared in 1852 when the Yellow River changed its course northwards and took over its bed. The current pronunciation of the character "Ji" with the third tone ("jǐ") was established in the late 1970s. Prior to this
column2: it was pronounced with the fourth tone ("jì"). Older texts spell the name as "Tsinan" (Wade-Giles romanization) or "Chi-nan".

column1: During the times of the Zhou dynasty (1045 BC to 256 BC)
column2: the city of Lixia (simplified Chinese: 历下; traditional Chinese: 歷下; pinyin: Lìxià) was the major settlement in the area. The name "Lixia" refers to the location of Jinan at the foot of Mount Li
column3: which lies to the south of the city). Today
column4: Lixia is the name of one of the city's districts.

column1: The Battle of An
column2: which was fought in the area during the Spring and Autumn period (in 589 BCE) between the states of Qi and Jin
column3: is named for the ancient city of Ān (Chinese: 鞍) which stood within the city limits of present-day Jinan. Marco Polo gives a brief description of Jinan under the name "Chingli" or "Chinangli". 19th and early 20th century texts frequently give the name of the city as "Tsinan Fu" where the additional "Fu" (Chinese: 府) comes from the dated Chinese term for a provincial capital (Chinese: 省府).

column1: Jinan is also referred to by the nickname "City of Springs" (Chinese: 泉城)
column2: because of the many artesian springs in the urban city centre and its surroundings.

column1: == History ==
=== Early history ===

The area of present-day Jinan has been inhabited for more than 4000 years. The Neolithic Longshan culture was first discovered at Chengziya to the east of Jinan (Zhangqiu District) in 1928. One of the characteristic features of the Longshan culture are the intricate wheel-made pottery pieces it produced. Most renowned is the black "egg-shell pottery" with wall thicknesses that can go below 1 millimeter.During the Spring and Autumn period (722–481 BCE) and Warring States period (475–221 BCE)
column2: the area of Jinan was split between two states: the state of Lu in the west and the state of Qi in the east. In 685 BCE
column3: the state of Qi started to build the Great Wall of Qi across Changqing county. Portions of the wall still remain today and are accessible as open air museums. Bian Que
column4: according to the legend the earliest Chinese physician and active around 500 BCE
column5: is said to have been a native of present-day Changqing County. Zou Yan (305–240 BCE)
column6: a native of Zhangqiu City
column7: developed the concepts of Yin-Yang and the Five Elements. Joseph Needham
column9: describes Zou as "The real founder of all Chinese scientific thought."During the times of the Han dynasty (206 BCE – 220 CE)
column10: Jinan was the capital of the feudatory Kingdom of Jibei (simplified Chinese: 济北国; traditional Chinese: 濟北國; pinyin: Jǐbĕi Guó) and evolved into the cultural and economic hub of the region. The Han dynasty tomb where the last king of Jibei
column11: Liu Kuan (刘宽; 劉寬; Liú Kuān)
column12: was buried at Shuangru Mountain  was excavated by archaeologists from Shandong University in 1995 and 1996. More than 2000 artifacts such as jade swords
column14: and jade pillows have been recovered within the 1
column16: emphasizing the wealth of the city during the period. Cao Cao (155 – 220 CE) was an official in Jinan before he became the de facto ruler of the Han dynasty. His son
column18: overthrew the last emperor of the Han and founded the Wei Kingdom (220 – 265 CE) of the Three Kingdoms Period.

column1: Beginning in the 5th century CE
column2: Buddhism flourished in Jinan. The Langgong Temple (朗公寺; Lǎnggōng Sì
column3: later renamed Shentong Temple
column4: (神通寺; Shéntōng Sì
column5: and now in ruins) in the southern county of Licheng was one of the most important temples in northern China at that time. The same period witnessed extensive construction of Buddhist sites in the southern counties of Licheng and Changqing such as the Lingyan Temple and the Thousand-Buddha Cliff. In particular
column6: a large number of cave temples were established in the hills south of Jinan.Jinan remained the cultural center of the region during the Song dynasty (960 – 1279 CE). The Song rulers promoted Jinan to a superior prefecture in 1116 CE. Two of the most important poets of the Southern Song were both born in Jinan: Li Qingzhao (1084–1151 CE)
column7: the most renown female poet in Chinese history
column9: who was also a military leader of the Southern Song dynasty. Both poets witnessed a series of crushing defeats of the Song dynasty at the hands of the Jurchens who gained control over almost half of the Song territories and established the Jin dynasty in northern China. After Jinan came under control of the Jin dynasty
column10: both Li Qingzhao and Xin Qiji had to abandon their homes and reflected this experience in their works.

column1: During the Civil War that followed the proclamation of Kublai Khan as Great Khan in 1260 CE
column2: Jinan was at the center of a rebellion by Yizhou governor Li Tan against Mongol rule in 1262 CE. The rebellion was crushed in a decisive battle that was fought not far from Jinan in late March or early April 1262 CE. After losing 4000 of his troops in the battle
column3: Li Tan retreated to Jinan to make his last stand. After defections of his defenders had made his position untenable
column4: Li Tan tried to commit suicide by drowning himself in Daming Lake. However
column5: he was rescued by the Mongols in order to execute him by trampling him to death with their horses.Despite such violent conflicts
column6: culture in Jinan continued to thrive during the Jin (1115–1234) and Yuan (1271–1368) dynasties: One of the most renowned artists of the Yuan dynasty
column7: Zhao Mengfu (1254–1322) was appointed to the post of governor of Jinan in 1293 and spent three years in the city. Among the extraordinary art works he completed during his stay in Jinan
column8: the best known painting is "Autumn Colors on the Qiao and Hua Mountains" (《鹊华秋色》). Geographer Yu Qin (1284–1333) also served as an official in Jinan and authored his geography book Qi Cheng there.

column1: When Shandong province was established under the Ming dynasty
column2: Jinan became its capital. Jinan was the site of a siege during the Jingnan Campaign where the city was defended by loyalists of the Jianwen Emperor led by Tie Xuan against the rebel Prince of Yan Zhu Di's army.

the northward shift of the Yellow River into a new bed close to the city triggered the modern expansion of Jinan. The new course of the Yellow River connected the city to the Grand Canal and regional waterways in northern Shandong and southern Hebei.German influence in Jinan grew after the Qing dynasty ceded Qingdao to the German Empire in 1897. A German concession area was established to the west of the historical city center (in the vicinity of the Jinan Railway Station first established by the Germans). The Jiaoji (Qingdao–Jinan) railway was built by the Germans against local resistance. Discontent over the construction of the railway was one of the sources fueling the Boxer Rebellion (1899–1901). During the rebellion
column3: foreign priests were evacuated from Jinan and Chinese Christians became a target of violence. The Jiaoji railway was completed in 1904
column4: three years after the Boxer Rebellion had been put down
column5: and opened the city to foreign trade. The importance of Jinan as a transportation hub was cemented with the completion of the north–south Jinpu railway from Tianjin to Pukou in 1912. Jinan became a major trading center for agricultural goods in northern China. Traded commodities included cotton
column6: grain
column7: peanuts
column8: and tobacco. Jinan also developed into a major industrial center
column9: second in importance to Qingdao in the province.

column1: === Republican era ===

column2: after the First World War
column3: the Japanese took over the German sphere of influence in Shandong
column4: including control of the Jiaoji railway
column5: and established a significant Japanese influence in Jinan. According to estimates by a contemporary Japanese government official
column6: about 2
column7: 000 Japanese were living in Jinan in 1931
column8: about half of whom were involved in the opium trade for which the Japanese had a loosely controlled monopoly that was exploited with the participation of Chinese traders.During the Warlord era of the Republic of China
column11: ruled Shandong from Jinan for a period that lasted from April 1925 until May 1928. Zhang was unpopular for his heavy-handed rule and in particular his heavy taxation. Besides heavy taxes
column12: he relied financially on opium to finance his periodic wars. Zhang even planned to use some of the wealth extracted from these sources for building a living shrine and a large bronze statue for himself on the shore of Daming Lake
column13: but these plans were not realized as his rule came to an end.

column1: In the spring of 1928
column2: the Kuomintang's Northern Expedition reached Jinan. On May 3
column4: clashes developed between Japanese troops stationed in Jinan and the Kuomintang troops moving into the city (Jinan Incident). Cai Gongshi
column5: a Kuomintang emissary sent to negotiate and 16 members of his entourage were cruelly executed by the Japanese. Japanese officers placed an order to slice off his nose and ears
column6: and to gouge out his eyes and tongue. Sixteen other members of his negotiation team were also striped naked
column7: recklessly whipped
column9: and slaughtered by machine guns on the same day. After the incident
column10: Japanese reinforcements were sent to Shandong and by 11 May
column11: Japanese troops pushed the Chinese troops from the area
column12: inflicted thousands of casualties and killed over 2000 Chinese civilians. The Japanese occupied Jinan for more than six months until they withdrew to their garrison in Tsingtao on the 28th of March 1929. When Chiang lectured a group of Chinese army cadets
column13: he urged them to turn their energies to washing away the shame of Jinan
column14: but to conceal their hatred until the last moment.  The Kuomintang government later decreed that May 3 be designated a "National Humiliation Memorial Day."

column1: During the Nanjing decade of the Republic of China
column2: Han Fuju
column3: a military commander from the warlord era who had aligned himself with the Kuomintang
column4: was rewarded with the military governorship of Shandong
column5: after fighting against the rebel troops of Yen Hsi-shan and his former commander Feng Yu-hsiang in the Central Plains War in 1930. He established his base in Jinan and is credited with curtailing banditry and drug trading
column6: thereby bringing a measure of peace and prosperity to the city. However
column7: from 1935 onwards Han was under heavy pressure from the Japanese consul in Jinan to declare Shandong an "independent state" allied with Japan.

column1: After the start of the Second Sino-Japanese War
column2: the Japanese invasion force crossed the Yellow River 60 km (37 mi) north-east of Jinan on December 23
column3: 1937. Han Fuju abandoned Jinan the next day against orders to hold the city to the death. He ordered the offices of the provincial government and the Japanese consulate in Jinan to be burned down and the ensuing power vacuum led to widespread looting in the city. Japanese troops from the 10th Division of the Manchurian Area Army entered Jinan on December 27
column4: 1937. Han Fuju was arrested and executed for disobeying orders from superior commanders and retreating on his own accord by Chiang Kai-Shek's chief of staff
column5: General Hu Zongnan.

column1: === After World War II ===
Japanese troops controlled Jinan until their defeat in 1945. After this
column2: the Kuomintang regained short-lived control of the city during the period from 1946 to 1948. The provincial government during this time was led by Lieutenant-General Wang Yaowu
column3: who also commanded the KMT army in the region. KMT rule over Jinan ended in September 1948 with the Battle of Jinan in which units of the People's Liberation Army under the command of Chen Yi took the city. The battle for Jinan took a decisive turn in favor of the attackers when KMT Lieutenant-General Wu Huawen  defected to the Communist side with about 8
column4: 000 of his troops. The most likely explanation for his defection is that he had been pressured through relatives of his who were held captive by the Communist forces. Lieutenant-General Wu had been in charge of the vital outer ring of defenses that protected the main airfield
column5: the railroad station
column6: and the commercial district. With these critical assets lost
column7: the situation of the city's defenders became untenable. Following the weakening of the city's defenses
column8: the People's Liberation Army breached the city wall and entered Jinan on September 24

column1: === Cultural Revolution ===
In March 1966
column2: the largest among the drawn-out sequence of earthquakes that made up the Xingtai earthquake damaged about 36
column3: 000 houses in Jinan.

column1: On May 27
column3: the Cultural Revolution started in Jinan with an article in the local newspaper "Jinan Evening News" (济南晚报) that denounced vice-governor Yu Xiu as a Bourgeois agent within the government. Starting from early June 1966
column4: the schools in Jinan were closed down by strikes as teachers were "struggled against". At the same time
column5: big-character posters started to appear in the city. Red Guards took to the streets of Jinan from late August 1966 onwards
column6: damaging cultural heritage and setting up courts to prosecute perceived enemies of the revolution. In the spring of 1967
column7: the "May 7th Incident" took place: When Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan
column8: both later reviled as members of the Gang of Four
column9: visited Jinan to support the Cultural Revolution and its local leader Wang Xiao Yu
column10: fighting erupted in the front of the provincial government between two rival factions of the Cultural Revolution
column11: the "April 22nd Group" and Wang Xiao Yu's "April 28th Group". In the end
column13: 000 people had been involved in the fighting. On October 11
column15: the tallest statue of Mao Zedong in Shandong province was erected on the campus of Shandong Normal University. On September 17
column17: a large assembly of Jinan workers celebrated the arrival of a mango fruit in the "August 1st" Meeting Hall. The fruit had been a gift to the workers in Beijing by Mao and was subsequently passed on to the workers in Jinan. In November 1968
column18: Wang Xiao Yu began to agitate against the local army units in Jinan and Shandong Province. By then unrest due to the Cultural Revolution had severely damaged the city's governmental and industrial infrastructure
column19: with about 80 percent of all government institutions shut down. Large public protests were staged on April 4 and 5
column22: 000 people protested the occupation of Zhenbao Island by the Soviet Union. On July 29
column24: the leadership of the Cultural Revolution passed a resolution to make sweeping changes to the city's educational system: The liberal arts departments of Shandong University were moved to Qufu and combined with Qufu Normal College to form a new Shandong University. The biology department was moved to Tai'an and merged into the Shandong Agricultural College. The rest of the sciences were to form the Shandong Science and Technology University. Shandong Normal University was to be moved to Liaocheng. Shandong Medical College and Shandong College of Traditional Chinese Medicine were to be merged and moved to Tai'an. Shandong University was restored in its original form and the "Shandong Science and Technology University" was abolished in early 1974. The first reversals of Cultural Revolution policies started in early 1971: On May 23 of that year
column25: the Shandong Provincial Museum was reopened after having been closed for about 5 years (since May 1966). In the next year
column26: the Jinan Committee for the Cultural Revolution officially reverted the name changes of four city districts enacted in 1966. During the 6 years between the name change and its reversal
column27: Lixia District had been known officially as "Hongwei"
column30: and Shizhong as "Red Flag". As the Cultural Revolution came to an end
column31: Jinan started to receive visitors from abroad. For example
column32: it was visited by a delegation from the United States Congress between August 8 and 11
column35: Mao's death was mourned by about 600
column36: 000 people at an official service in Jinan's August 1 Square.

column1: Jinan was the host of the 11th All China Games during October 2009. These games are the selection games for the Chinese Olympic champions. For this occasion
column2: security was heightened and a full volunteer force was out on the streets directing visitor traffic. The city conducted major renovations in its transportation and recreation services in anticipation of the Games' visitors.2019

column1: At the beginning of January
column2: the State Council of the People's Republic of China approved the approval of Shandong Province to adjust the administrative division of Laiwu City and Jinan City
column3: cancel Laiwu City
column4: and all jurisdiction of former Laiwu City belongs to Jinan City; establish Laiwu District of Jinan City to replace the former Laicheng District of Laiwu City with the same administrative area; establish Gangcheng District of Jinan City to replace the former Gangcheng District of Laiwu City with the same administrative area.

column1: == Geography and climate ==
=== Geography ===
Jinan is located in the north-western part of Shandong province at 36° 40′ northern latitude and 116° 57′ east of Greenwich
column2: about 400 kilometres (250 mi) south of the national capital of Beijing. It borders Liaocheng to the southwest
column3: Dezhou to the northwest
column4: Binzhou to the northeast
column5: Zibo to the east
column6: and Tai'an to the south. In the relief of the region
column7: the city occupies a transition zone between the northern foothills of the Taishan Massif to the south of the city and the valley of the Yellow River to the north. Karst aquifers in limestone formations sloping down from the south to the north give rise to many artesian springs in the city center as well as in surrounding areas.

column1: === Climate ===
Jinan has a humid subtropical (Köppen: Cwa)
column2: considering a normal isotherm of −3 °C
column3: or a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dwa)
column4: considering an isotherm of 0 °C but favoring the former
column5: with four well-defined seasons. The city is dry and nearly rainless in spring
column6: hot and rainy in summer
column7: crisp in autumn and dry and cold (with little snow) in winter. The average annual temperature is 14.70 °C (58.5 °F)
column8: and the annual precipitation is around slightly above 670 millimetres (26.4 in)
column10: and high variability from year to year. January is the coldest and driest month
column11: with a mean temperature of −0.4 °C (31.3 °F) and 5.7 millimetres (0.22 in) of equivalent rainfall. July is the hottest and wettest month
column13: and 201.3 mm (7.93 in). With monthly percent possible sunshine ranging from 48 percent in July to 63 percent in May

column1: Due to the mountains to the south of the city
column2: temperature inversions are common
column3: occurring on about 200 days per year. The high precipitation for northern Chinese standards
column4: in tandem with the topography (mountains surrounding the city on three sides)
column5: leads to particularly oppressive summer weather and the city being named as a candidate for the fourth "furnace"
column6: c.e. Three Furnaces.

column1: Extremes since 1951 have ranged from −19.7 °C (−3 °F) on 17 January 1953 to 42.5 °C (109 °F) on 24 July 1955.
=== Air quality ===
According to the National Environmental Analysis released by Tsinghua University and The Asian Development Bank in January 2013
column2: Jinan is one of ten most air polluted cities in the world. Also according to this report
column3: 7 of 10 most air polluted cities are in China
column4: including Taiyuan
column5: Beijing
column6: Urumqi
column7: Lanzhou
column9: Jinan and Shijiazhuang. As air pollution in China is at an all-time high
column10: several northern cities are among the most polluted cities and has one of the worst air quality in China. Reporting on China's air quality has been accompanied by what seems like a monochromatic slideshow of the country's several cities smothered in thick smog. According to a survey made by "Global voices China" in February 2013
column11: Jinan is among China's 10 most polluted cities
column12: and is the only Shandong city to be on this list. Other cities on the blacklist includes major Chinese cities like Beijing
column15: and 6 other prefectural cities all in Hebei Province. These cities are all situated in traditional geographic subdivision of "Huabei (North China) Region".

column1: A dense wave of smog began in the Central and Eastern part of China on 2 December 2013 across a distance of around 1
column2: 200 kilometres (750 mi)
column3: including Jinan and surrounding Shandong area. A lack of cold air flow
column4: combined with slow-moving air masses carrying industrial emissions
column5: collected airborne pollutants to form a thick layer of smog over the region. Officials blamed the dense pollution on lack of wind
column6: automobile exhaust emissions under low air pressure
column7: and coal-powered district heating system in North China region. Prevailing winds blew low-hanging air masses of factory emissions (mostly SO2) towards China's east coast.

column1: == Administrative divisions ==
The sub-provincial city of Jinan has direct jurisdiction over ten districts and 2 counties after the annexation of Laiwu to Jinan in 2019:
These are further divided into 146 township-level divisions
column2: including 65towns
column3: 27 townships and 54 subdistricts.

column1: == Economy ==
With the shift of the Yellow River to a new bed right to the north of Jinan (in 1852) and the establishment of a railroad hub
column2: the city became a major market for agricultural products from the productive farming regions to the north.

column1: Following the trade in agricultural goods
column2: the city developed a textile and clothing industry
column3: flour mills
column4: oil presses
column5: as well as factories producing paper
column6: cement
column7: and matches. In the 1950s
column8: large iron and steel works as well as chemical factories were established around Jinan. The large metal works produce pig iron
column10: as well as finished steel. In 2008
column11: steel manufacturing was restructured with the formation of the Shandong Iron and Steel Group.

column1: In the 1970s
column2: Sinotruk established its headquarters and factories for the production of trucks and construction vehicles in the city.Jinan has a pool of high-quality labor resources. There are 18 universities and colleges in the city where more than 200
column3: 000 students are studying. Among the over 200 research institutes in the city
column4: 10 are national laboratories.

column1: The focus on technology-intensive industries has transformed Jinan from a city supported by heavy industry and textiles to a city with more diverse industrial structure. Information Technology
column2: transportation tools
column3: home appliances
column4: and bio-engineered products
column5: among others
column6: have become important components of the area's industry. Jinan's IT-related economic output was ranked to be in the fourth place nationally in 2004.

column1: Industrial zones include:
Jinan High-tech Industrial Development ZoneFounded in 1991
column2: the Jinan High-tech Industrial Development zone was one of the first of its kind approved by the State Council. The zone is located to the east of the city and covers a total planning area of 83 km2 (32 sq mi) that is divided into a central area covering 33 km2 (13 sq mi)
column3: an export processing district of 10 km2 (3.9 sq mi)
column4: and an eastern extension area of 40 km2 (15 sq mi).

column1: Since its foundation
column2: the Jinan High-tech Industrial Development Zone has attracted enterprises as LG
column3: Panasonic
column4: Volvo
column5: and Sanyo. In 2000
column6: it joined the world science and technology association and set up a China-Ukraine High-tech Cooperation Park. The Qilu Software Park became the sister park of Bangalore park of India.

column1: Jinan Export Processing ZoneThe export processing zone is located in the eastern suburbs of Jinan
column2: to the east of the Jinan High-tech Industrial Development Zone and to the north of the Jiwang highway. The distances to the Jiqing Highway and the Jinan Airport are 9 km (5.6 mi) and 18 km (11 mi) respectively.

column1: Liaocheng Economic Development Zone
== Demographics ==

column2: the estimated population of the entire area under the jurisdiction of Jinan City was 5.69 million
column3: with a total of 2.54 million living in urban areas. By 2009
column4: the total population had grown to about six million. The census in 2010 counted 6.814 million inhabitants out of which about 4.335 million were living in 6 urban districts which made up the built-up area.The encompassing metropolitan area was estimated by the OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) to have
column5: as of 2010
column6: a population of 11 million.The population is predominantly Han (98.3 percent)
column7: with very small portions of Hui and Manchu Chinese. Jinan has a significant Muslim community centred in the city's Muslim quarter
column8: located to the west of the historical center.

column1: == Culture and contemporary life ==
=== Dialect ===
Local residents in the city proper
column2: as well as in the surrounding areas
column3: have traditionally spoken the Jinan dialect of Mandarin that is not readily understood even by native speakers of standard Mandarin. The younger people of Jinan are more likely to speak standard Mandarin
column4: whereas many older residents retain strong local dialect elements in their speech. Nevertheless
column5: even the younger residents of Jinan tend to retain a strong local accent and mix local vocabulary into the standardized Mandarin vocabulary. Due to the influx of migrant workers during the past decade of China's economic boom
column6: many of the current population that are of working age are not natives of Jinan but have learned to understand the Jinan dialect.

column1: === Cuisine ===
Jinan has its own cuisine
column2: the Jinan style of the Shandong cuisine
column3: one of the Eight Culinary Traditions of China. One of its features is the use of soup in its dishes. Modern cuisines in northern China —Beijing
column4: Tianjin and the northeastern regions including Heilongjiang
column5: Jilin and Liaoning— are all branches of Shandong cuisine.

column1: === Shopping centers ===

Most shopping malls in Jinan are in the downtown area centered around Spring City Square and Quancheng Road (泉城路; 'spring city road'). Spring City Square was built by the municipal government beside the city moat in the early 21st century; at the center is the statue "Spring" which has become a symbol of Jinan. The square borders on the ancient city moat. It has a music fountain
column3: 000 square meter underground shopping center and a memorial hall with statues of famous people from Shandong.

column1: Spring City Road was rebuilt at the same time that Spring City Square was created. The government's intention was to create a modern business district and yet preserve the traditional Chinese culture. Therefore
column2: newly built shopping malls with traditional Chinese architectural styles and modern western skyscrapers can be found side by side along Spring City Road. Notable retail businesses are Quancheng Bookstore – the largest bookstore of the city – and Walmart (near the western end of Spring City Road). Major shopping malls along the road are the Guihe Shopping Center (贵和商厦)
column3: the Sofitel Silver Plaza
column4: the Shimao international shopping center
column5: and the Wanda Shopping Mall (万达集团). Parc 66 (济南恒隆广场) to the south of Spring City Road (opposite of Water Lily Street)
column6: opened in August 2011
column7: is Jinan's largest shopping mall with seven levels of retail space and a total gross floor area of 171

=== Transportation ===
==== Railways ====
Jinan is positioned at the intersection of two major railways: The Jinghu Railway that runs from Beijing to Shanghai is the major north–south backbone of the railway system in eastern China. In Jinan
column2: it intersects with the Jiaoji Railway that connects Jinan to the sea port of Qingdao to the east. In addition
column3: the Hanji Railway connects Jinan to the city of Handan (Hebei Province) in the west.

column1: Within Shandong province
column2: the Jinghu Railway connects Jinan with the cities of Dezhou
column3: Tai'an
column4: Jining
column5: and Zaozhuang; the Jiaoji Railway provides a link to the cities of Zibo
column6: Qingdao
column7: and Weifang; the Hanji Railway serves the cities of Yancheng and Liaocheng.

column1: Central Jinan is served by the Jinan Railway Station and the Jinan East Railway Station (just by Daming Lake).
The Beijing–Shanghai High-Speed Railway calls at Jinan West railway station
column2: which is outside the central metropolitan center and is in suburban western Jinan's Huaiyin District. Since it opened for public service on 30 June 2011
column3: it has become a future hub with west–east running high speed railways to Taiyuan
column4: Shijiazhuang and Qingdao. Jinan East railway station opened in 2018.

column1: ==== Expressways ====
Major expressways include China National Highway 104
column2: China National Highway 220
column3: and China National Highway 309. Because of Jinan's location and role as a road and rail transportation hub
column4: the Jinan Coach Terminus has one of the largest passenger flows nationally. On peak travel days
column5: as many as 92
column6: 000 passengers per day have been counted
column7: on off-peak days the number is around 42

column1: ==== Airport ====

Jinan Yaoqiang International Airport is located about 33 km (21 mi) northeast of the city center and to the north of the town of Yaoqiang from which the name of the airport is derived. The airport is connected to the city center of Jinan by expressways. It has domestic flights to many of the major cities in China as well as to international destinations
column2: in particular Helsinki
column3: Osaka
column4: Seoul
column5: Paris
column6: Bangkok and Singapore.

column1: ==== Public transportation ====
Jinan's urban public transportation history began in 1938
column2: and the city is now a major bus transportation hub. To ensure that buses have priority
column3: most of the city's urban main roads have a bus lane
column4: and bus rapid transit signal priority measures are gradually being implemented. The Jinan urban area has more than 220 public transportation routes.

column1: According to the properties of bus lines
column2: Jinan's urban bus network can be divided into five categories:

column1: Bus rapid transit system: The Jinan BRT has 7 routes
column2: connected by transfer stations. As a result of the BRT's isolated central lanes
column3: signal priority and other measures
column4: bus speeds have been greatly improved
column5: improving public transport. Price:￥2.

column1: Conventional buses: Have air-conditioned and non-air-conditioned buses. Air-conditioned lines have a K perfix on their route numbers. Form 2018
column2: most lines are air-conditioned lines (Include lines without K perfix). These lines comprise more than 200 routes covering the whole city. Price:￥1 (Air-conditioned is￥2).

column1: Public trolleybuses: the Jinan trolleybus system
column2: opened in 1977
column3: once had 10 lines
column4: but now has only four. These are Jinan's most important bus routes. Price: ￥1.

column1: Suburban and exurban buses – Operated by air-conditioned and non-air-conditioned vehicles. Most of these buses carries passengers from suburban/exurban area to urban area
column2: while the others provide village-to-village or village-to-county service. Price: Varies from ￥1 to ￥12.

column1: Student
column2: supermarket and particular business bus lines – These are for large schools
column3: supermarkets
column4: business transfer students
column5: customers
column6: employees of private businesses. They operate side by side with the other bus systems.Started by construction in 2013
column7: Jinan Metro will open in 2018 and then will be extended to 3 lines toward 2030.

column1: == Main tourist attractions ==
Jinan is renowned across China for its numerous springs
column2: the lakes fed by the spring water
column3: and the weeping willows that grow along the water edges. The late-Qing author Liu E describes Jinan's cityscape in his novel "The Travels of Lao Can" (老残游记
column4: written 1903–04
column5: published in 1907) as "Every family has spring water
column6: every household has a willow tree". Jinan was also the historical center of Buddhist culture for the whole province which is still manifest in the many historic sites that are left behind in its southern counties.

column1: === Springs and lakes ===
Jinan is known as the "City of Springs" because of the large number of natural artesian springs. The majority of the springs
column2: many of which have been historically listed under the "72 Famous Springs" (七十二名泉) are concentrated in the downtown district and flow north to converge in Daming Lake. The Baotu Spring Park is the most popular of the springs in the City of Jinan proper. Besides the Baotu Spring
column3: the park contains several other springs that are listed among the "72 Famous Springs". "Bào tū" (趵突) means "jumping and leaping" in Chinese. The water in the spring pool can be seen foaming and gushing
column4: looking like a pot of boiling water. The spring was visited by the Qianlong Emperor (1711–1799) of the Qing dynasty who declared it "the best spring under the heaven" (Chinese: 天下第一泉; pinyin: tiān xià dì yī quán). A tablet with the Emperor's handwriting "Baotu Spring" has since been erected beside the spring pool.

column1: Not far away to the northeast of Baotu Spring Park is the Daming Lake
column2: which
column3: together with Baotu Spring and the Thousand-Buddha Mountain is often regarded as the "Three Greatest Attractions in Jinan". Other notable parks in the city include the Five Dragon Pool (五龙潭) near the Baotu Spring Park
column4: the Black Tiger Spring (黑虎泉) on the southern city moat
column5: and the Baimai Springs (百脉泉) of Zhangqiu City to the east of Jinan.

column1: === Buddhist sites ===
Historic Buddhist sites are particularly common in Licheng County to the south-east of the city center of Jinan. The Four Gates Pagoda
column2: built in 661
column3: is the oldest existing one-story stone tower in China. The pagoda houses four Buddhist statues dating from the 6th century
column4: and the Cypress tree (九顶松) standing next to the pagoda is more than 1000 years old. Below the hill on which pagoda stands lie the remnants of the Shentong Temple (神通寺)
column5: which was founded in the 4th century but was destroyed in the wars of later dynasties. The funerary stelae of monks from the temple which date from different historic periods display remarkable artistic features. The statues in the nearby Thousand-Buddha Cliff form one of the best collections of Tang dynasty Buddhist statues in the region.

column1: The Lingyan Temple in the southern county of Changqing was one of the four most famous temples (四大名刹) of the Tang dynasty. The temple was founded during the Jin dynasty and reached its heyday during the Tang and Song dynasties. During the Tang dynasty
column2: the famous monk Xuanzang stayed in the temple and translated Buddhist manuscripts he had brought to China from India. Many emperors in Chinese history visited the temple before they went to Mount Tai (one of China's five sacred mountains
column3: located south of Jinan) for ceremonies. The clay sculptures of Buddhas made in the Song dynasty are considered as "The Best of China" by scholar and journalist Liang Qichao. Buddhist architectures within the temple such as pagodas and tomb stelae are among the earliest and best protected in the region.

column1: === Museums and libraries ===

The Shandong Provincial Museum located at the foothill of Thousand-Buddha Mountain is the largest museum in the province. It has a large collection of natural as well as historical treasures from the whole province. The museum was established in its present form in 1982 and currently has 8 exhibition halls : "Treasures of Shandong Province"; "Stone Sculptures"; "Warship of the Ming dynasty"; "Ancient Coins"; "Art Treasures"; "Fossil Collections"; "Dinosaurs"; and "Specimens". The museum has more than 210
column2: 000 relics and specimens
column3: making up ⅓ of the collections in museums of whole province. The Shandong Provincial Museum has been ranked No. 7 in terms of collection size among the museums of China.The Shandong Art Museum holds a large collection of fine arts.

column1: The Jinan Municipal Museum  is located at the south-western foot of the Thousand-Buddha Mountain
column2: in the north of the city center. Although much smaller than the provincial museum
column3: the municipal museum still houses a collection of more than 20
column4: 000 items
column5: most of which were recovered in the city area.

column1: The Shandong Provincial Library  in the eastern High-tech Park (address: 2912 Second Ring East Road) is the principal library of the province and is ranked among the Top 10 Chinese libraries. As of 2004
column2: the library had more than 5.18 million documents
column3: many of which date back many centuries and are important sources for research on Chinese history. The library also has a large collection of western journals/books. Originally
column4: the library was built close to Daming Lake in 1909 by the then governor of Shandong. In the late 1990s
column5: a project was undertaken to move the library to the eastern part of the city
column6: and it reopened in 2002 with 35 reading rooms and more than 2000 seats.

column1: === Parks and Nature Reserves ===
Jinan Hundred Miles Yellow River Scenic Area is located in No.166 Luokou Huancheng Road in Tianqiao District. It is designed as an ecological cultural theme park which focuses on ecological tourism
column2: cultural tourism
column3: and healthy tourism. The Yellow River of this section stretches 51.98 kilometers. Jinan Hundred Miles Yellow River Scenic Area was awarded the title "Fifty Scenes of the Yellow River in China" on September 12
column4: 2018. The Levee extending along the Yellow River in this scenery area
column5: is praised as "the Great Wall over water".Yellow River Forest Park (Jinan) is located on the north bank of the Yellow River. The Yellow River Forest Park sprawls over 1500mu (100 hectares) and has 300
column6: 000 trees of various breeds. Yellow River Forest Park is the only park equipping with a forest racecourse
column7: which has a course of 3 Li (unit)
column8: in Jinan City. Yellow River Forest Park provides not only an area covering 5000 square meters for visitors to freely barbecue but also a fishing pond covering 1
column9: 800 square meters. Visitors can participate in various activities here

column1: Daming Lake Park is located in the center of Jinan City
column2: covering an area of 46.5 hectares. Daming Lake Park is considered as one of the "Three Must-see Tourist Spots of Jinan" (the others are Baotu Spring Park and Thousand-Buddha Mountain). Daming Lake Park has many scenic spots
column3: such as the Daming lake and the Lixia Pavilion. Daming Lake is a natural lake consisting of many springs. It is unique because the lake has constant water level unaffected by heavy rains or drought. Lixia Pavilion
column4: which was built in the Northern Wei period
column5: is in the center of the Daming Lake. There are so many ancient buildings in Daming Lake Park that it has a title describing them
column6: which is "One terrace
column7: three gardens

== Military ==
Jinan is the former command center for the Jinan Military Region
column2: one of the defunct seven military regions into which the People's Liberation Army is organized. Jinan MR was considered as a strategic reserve of PLA. Jinan Military Region covered two of China's most populous provinces
column3: Henan and Shandong.

column1: == Sports ==

The most renowned sports team in Jinan are the Shandong Golden Lions. The Shandong Golden Lions have been playing in the Chinese top basketball league for all the seasons (13 for basketball) since the league turned professional in 1995. The team's best season was 1997–1998 when it finished 3rd place. In the 2007–2008 season
column2: the Shandong Golden Lions also reached the 3rd place at the end of the season
column3: but they were knocked out at the first round of the playoffs.

column1: The Shandong Luneng Football Club is the most widely known football team in Jinan. The club currently plays at the highest tier of Chinese football
column2: the Chinese Super League. The Shandong Luneng Football Club is one of four clubs which have been playing in Chinese top football league every season since the league turned professional in 1994. Since 1994 the club has won 9 titles: Top League Champions (1999
column6: FA Cups (1995
column10: and CSL Cup (2004). Jinan was also one of four host cities of China during 2004 AFC Asian Cup.

column2: Jinan hosted the 2009 National Games of China
column3: the premier sports event at the national level in China and the first major multi-sports event held in China after the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing. The National Games' main venue was the Jinan Olympic Sports Center.From 2014 Jinan is well known also as place of Chinese national winter swimming festivals at Daming Lake
column4: since 2016 organized in cooperation with International Winter Swimming Association (IWSA). And in season 2019/2020 Jinan has become for the first time Chinese site of international winter swimming World cup  (as its 3rd stage  under the IWSA-rules).
